title: Interior artificial lighting and power control

contentBlocks.title: General lighting control requirements
items: All artificial lighting must be individually controlled by a switch or control device
Switches must be visible and easily accessed, generally in the room itself except for specialized spaces like auditoriums

contentBlocks.title: Sole-occupancy unit requirements
items: In a sole-occupancy unit of a Class 3 building (not designed for accommodation of the aged or people with a disability), an occupant activated device must cut power to lighting, air conditioning, exhaust fans, and bathroom heater when the unit is unoccupied

contentBlocks.title: Requirements for buildings over 250 m²
items: 95% of light fittings in a building greater than 250 m² must be controlled by a time switch or occupant sensing device (motion detector, key card)
In Class 5, 6, and 7 buildings, natural lighting zones adjacent to windows must have separate control
Artificial lighting in fire-isolated stair/passage/ramp must be controlled by motion detector
Foyers/corridors exceeding 250 W zone and adjacent to windows must be controlled by daylight sensor and dynamic lighting control device
Carpark entry zone first 19m (daytime): daylight sensor required
